title: 2,4-Dinitroanisole
text:
2,4-Dinitroanisole (DNAN) is a low sensitivity organic compound. It has an <a href="anisole">anisole</a> (methoxybenzene) core, with two <a href="nitro%20group">nitro group</a>s (–NO2) attached.
It is not explosive itself unless it is mixed with other explosive chemicals in certain ratios. Compared with TNT it has only 90% of the explosive power and is less dense with a higher melting point.
Properties.
2,4-Dinitroanisole crystallises in the <a href="monoclinic">monoclinic</a> form. The unit cell has these sizes and angles: a=8.772 Å b=12.645 Å c=15.429 Å 81.89°, cell volume is V=1694 Å3, There are eight molecules in each <a href="unit%20cell">unit cell</a>, with four positions symmetric. The two asymmetric positions have the molecule bent in different ways. The <a href="methyl%20group">methyl group</a> can be rotated either at 5° or 13° out of the plane of the benzene ring. The "<a href="Arene%20substitution%20pattern%23Ortho%2C%20meta%2C%20and%20para%20substitution">ortho</a>" nitro group is rotated at 3° or 35°. The "<a href="Arene%20substitution%20pattern%23Ortho%2C%20meta%2C%20and%20para%20substitution">para</a>" nitro group is close to parallel with the ring plane.
The <a href="specific%20heat">specific heat</a> of solid 2,4-dinitroanisole is given by Cp (Jmol−1K−1) = 0.3153 + 0.00265T (T in K). At 298.15 K. it is 219.02 Jmol−1K−1 The <a href="melting%20enthalpy">melting enthalpy</a> is 20.2 kJmol−1 and <a href="solidification%20heat">solidification heat</a> is 19.7 kJmol−1. These can differ so much as the liquid can be <a href="supercool">supercool</a>ed 22.8 °C. The initial decomposition temperature is 295 °C, and the explosion temperature is 312 °C. On explosion the adiabatic temperature rise is 4923 °C. Ignition temperature is 347 °C.
Reactions.
2,4-Dinitroanisole reacts without heat with a <a href="potassium%20cyanide">potassium cyanide</a> solution to form a red coloured product via the <a href="isopurpuric%20acid%20reaction">isopurpuric acid reaction</a>. In this cyanide is added in the meta position, and the ortho nitro group is reduced to -NHOH.
In alkaline conditions DNAN can be attacked at the methoxy position with nucleophiles to form <a href="Meisenheimer%20complex">Meisenheimer complex</a>es. In these the ring develops a negative charge and another group is attached at the methoxy attachment point. So for example, sodium methoxide can produce the 6,6-dimethoxy-1,3-dinitro-1,3-cyclohexadiene anion.
When heated under pressure with water and ammonia DNAN is converted to <a href="2%2C4-dinitroaniline">2,4-dinitroaniline</a>.
With iron and acetic acid DNAN nitro groups can be reduced to amines forming <a href="2%2C4-diaminoanisole">2,4-diaminoanisole</a>.
Formation.
2,4-Dinitroanisole can be formed from "p"-nitroanisole or "o"-nitroanisole nitration. Also it can be formed from <a href="1-chloro-2%2C4-dinitrobenzene">1-chloro-2,4-dinitrobenzene</a> by treatment with <a href="sodium%20methoxide">sodium methoxide</a> (sodium in methanol) or <a href="sodium%20hydroxide">sodium hydroxide</a> with <a href="methanol">methanol</a>.
Over a period of days, alkalies will hydrolyse the ether bond to form <a href="2%2C4-dinitrophenol">2,4-dinitrophenol</a>.
Use.
2,4-Dinitroanisole is used as an explosive replacing TNT. It is used in explosive mixtures such as <a href="IMX-101">IMX-101</a>, <a href="IMX-104">IMX-104</a>, <a href="PAX-48">PAX-48</a>, <a href="PAX-21">PAX-21</a> and <a href="PAX-41">PAX-41</a> in the <a href="spider%20grenade">spider grenade</a>. It can be melted and cast more safely. It has also been used as a dye ingredient and insecticide.
Environment.
When mixed with soil, 2,4-dinitroanisole is modified by bacteria through the path 2-nitroso-4-nitroanisole, 2-hydroxyamino-4-nitroanisole to 2-amino-4-nitroanisole. This takes place on a time scale of a few weeks. In the human body it is converted to <a href="2%2C4-dinitrophenol">2,4-dinitrophenol</a>. Recent reports, demonstrated that a Nocardia sp. bacterium was able to mineralize 2, 4-dinitroanisole as a sole carbon source, via well established 2,4-dinitrophenol pathway.
